review_blob: this beer cascades slowly into a glass like an espresso mixed with molasses, thick like oil - almost gurgling.  it is of the darkest shade of brown with a thin hazelnut colored head.  it is smooth and rich, with a finish of dark cherries, bulgar, and cacoa.  fundamentally strong and classic in its endeavor, truly delicious, far from revolutionary.
beer_name: Stone 20th Anniversary Encore Series: Bitter Chocolate Oatmeal Stout

review_blob:
pours cloudy and rusted
foamy with a soft peak head
oatsy, soft citrus, caramel and vanilla
so drinkable it makes me nervous



on the beer engine, the map room
chicago, illinois
beer_name: Two Brothers Bare Tree Weiss Wine (2002 and later)

review_blob:
smooth and drinkable.  pours a clean light yellow.  not much on the nose.  fruit, hops, mild flavors that balance well for the high alcohol content.  finishes slightly tart and dry.
on tap @ the map room
chicago, il

pours a beautiful rusted amber with a full creamy head.  hoppy and sweet in the nose.   stone fruit in the mouth.  crisp and clean.  really good on the first  spring day in chicago. 
on tap @ the map room
UPDATED: MAY 3, 2008

pours an almost whiskey color with a thin subtle yellow head.  really light on the palate.    lots of spice in the nose.  notes include subtle vanilla, spices, hops and alcohol.  not of their best but a decent effort.
on tap @ goose island brewery
chicago, il

wow. this beer is great. pours easy with a dark rusted amber color and lively head.  impressive in the nose.  notes of raisins, caramel, spices, molasses.  really impressive.
bottle from sams
chicago, il

notes of liquorice, spices (coriander, nutmeg, clove), orange.  pours a beautiful brown with a big head.  nice, creamy mouthfeel.  good beer.
bottle from sams
chicago, il

simply put, one of the best.  the breakfast stout in itself is fantastic but add the oak barrel aging and you get added notes of vanilla, oak, and of course bourbon.  i gave one of my four pack to a friend from new hampshire, he said it was the best beer he had ever had.
pours oily black nice deep espresso head.  noes of coffee, roast, chocolate, liquorice, and pine.
one of the best ipas made in the country.  this beer is crisp and delicious. notes of coriander citrus, and beautifully floral hops.  i reach for it often.

if it were socially acceptable id have one of these in the morning everyday.  really bold with the amount of coffee.  pours pitch black with a great head.  aroma and taste stick together in this not too complicated just up-front coffee stout.  delicious.

i love sweet stouts.  they give you that big body with a more complex flavor.  and theyre fun to pair with food.  this one pours black and along with its roasted maltyed body this one starts cherry and finishes cherry.  interesting beer.  no de dolle.
damn fine beer.  nice and roasty with notes molasses, chocolate, vanilla, and liquorice.  really great mouthfeel.  i love bells.
pours muddy with a tan head.  nice and rich.  notes are typical.  not too bad, not too good.
nice dark pour, creamy head.  notes of chocolate and malt.  big and rich, but about average.  make sure its not too cold when you drink it this beer really opens up with the warmth of your hands.

i like to think of sierra pale as the friend back in your home town who is always at the bar during holidays.  you know hell be there, everywhere in fact and while you might not specifically look for him when you go home you know hell be there and its comforting.  the old satand by that is well balnced, hoppy, fruity and dry.  great in the summer at a show or in the backyard tossing boules.

oh barley wine, how many ridiculous things have i done because of you?  youre complex and beautiful but you like to toss me to the curb. and id like to do the same withthe bigfoot.  pours thick and murky with a heavy handed taste of alcohol, not the balance i want from you.  you have to be subtle and delicate before you knock me out.  bigfoot doesnt.
cloudy pour, style right?  wheat in the nose, spice in the mouth.  its subtle, its light, its not for me.
i really like this belgian strong.  pours amber with a light whited head.  good sweet and sour notes.  finishes clean with a nice subtle pucker at the end.
this beer is great ans widely aavailable where ive lived recenty (KY, NY, and Il). pours black with a nice creamy head.  notes include chocolate, hazelnut, and molasses.  really excellent.
beer_name: North Coast Old Rasputin Russian Imperial Stout

review_blob: above average apa.  nice copper color, good head.  pronounced hops in the nose and mouth. orange and creamy.  solid beer from a solid brewery

i like this red rye.  nice crimson color, pronounced hops and pine.  good mouthfeel and excellent finish.  its biting and smooth all at the same time.
on tap @ the map room
chicago, illinois

this beer is quite beautiful when poured. nice effervescent white head with a beautiful orange color. clean mouthfeel with notes of vanilla citrus, and banana.  decent, but not a hefe fan.
bottle @ blackbird
Chicago, Illinois
nice deep golden amber color with a aerated white head.  wheaty, with lots of citric acid and good floral notes.  not my favorite style but a good example of a wheat.

poured a syrupy, oily dark black with almost no head.  nice and roasty in the nose with vanilla and anise.  heavy roasted malt notes, liquorice, coffee, macintosh apples, and bana na na.  really delicious, great cough syrup mouthfeel, good for one, no two, ok four.
beer_name: Dark Horse Plead the 5th Imperial Stout

review_blob:
really nice citrus aroma.  beautiful pour of rusted mahogany with a creamy head.  slightly watery flavor, like most irish ales for me. not bad
on tap @ the map room

not so impressed here.  nose lacks much, some coffee.  notes of roasted barley, cocoa, malt.  palate is biting at the end and relatively flat.
on tap @ the map room
hot cocoa malty richness, ovaltine with alcohol.  i loved this place, this beer, now these memories.  one of my favorite stouts ever.  it does everything for you.
this stout abounds.  pours beautifully black with a big ole tan head, even out of the bottle.  notes of oats, roasted coffee, malt, bitter chocolate,vanilla, star anise.  nice, i like.
this a decent and accessible porter.  notes of coffee, cream, roasted malt, vanilla.  nothing extravagent going on here just a nice well balanced porter.  good to go.

this is a safety net beer, one i can find a lot of places that i like more than other common micros. its buttery like movie theatre popcorn, only there is not corn just popped hops? thats a strange one but the way i feel.  stone fruit too, not peach, not nectarine, not apricot but somehow a concoction of all of them.  i dig rogue and dont know what a heller bock is but when im in louisville at the outlook and the bourbon is too much i reach for a dead guy.

ehh. thats the review and the sentiment.  not much to write here.  its true that its well balanced and a good introduction to the apa which can kill newcomers with overt hoppiness but it just doesnt do much for me.
pours an aged copper with a big fluffy head.  notes of caramel, raisin, apples, toffee, and alcohol.  really quite a nice experiment and a nice beer.

for my 100th rating i splurged.  this beer is absolutely wonderful, a true gift from my favorite belgian brewery.  pours an esteemed roasted brown color with a cumulus cloud head.  it smells of coriander, apples, and oak.  notes of vanilla, grapes, cherries and pears.  the aging in the bordeaux barrels does wonders to smooth out the alcohol dominance of regular oerbier.  i love it, wish i could afford it more often and will someday make a special pilgrimage to diksmuide.

bottle @ the map room

pours like molasses, deep black imperial stout with a rather disappointing espresso colored head that dissipates quickly.  notes of roasted coffee, barley, tobacco, milk chocolate.  really luscious.  could be more long lasting on the palate, kind of playful but fleeting. 
bottle @ the map room
a tribute to orval from greg.  decent belgian style ale.  cloudy yellow pour with almost no head.  tartness of fresh fall apples and citrus notes.  nice balance of malt to go with astringent hops.
pours a deep black with little to no head.  toasty, roasty aromas.  notes of chocolate, rhubarb, and coffee.
gross, gross, gross.  im not against rice.  im a cook i love rice, but not in a beer.  boo to the king" of beers.

great english strong.  beautiful pour of dark molasses and an opaque white head.  notes of vanilla and oak.  kind of like a bourbon in a beer.  good for an old kentucky boy.  nice weight for a strong ale, plays like a well brewed cafe on the tongue.  really good.
on tap @ the map room

pours a rich, dark black with a creamy espresso head.  good lacing.  fruity notes, sweet cherries, vanilla, dont get the coffee others describe.  alcohol notes, more hops than i like in an imperial stout.  airy palate that tingles the inside of your cheeks.  good, not greaat.
on tap @ the map room

this beer pours beautifully.  a deep black murkiness reminiscent of a perfectly brewed espresso.  it has a striking golden head that bubbles like the witches cauldron of macbeth.  its lacing falters down the stretch but still has a great appearance.  notes of coffee beans, liquorice, chocolate, malt, and a really surprising finish of lavender and hops.  quite remarkable.
beer_name: Southern Tier Jah-va Imperial Coffee Stout

review_blob: this beer is like a beautiful red headed woman, fiery, temperamental yet worth every minute of your time.  she pours a deep rusted red, the most beautiful youve ever seen, you remember anouk aimee in "8 1/2", rita hayworth in "gilda."  what head does exist is a perfect ivory with the slightest bit of lacing.  let this beer dance on your palate, its complex and longstanding, it tickles you here and pounds you there.  it sticks there with a fieriness found few other places.  notes include bitter orange, fresh tobacco, star anise, vanilla, barley. honeycrisp apples, and so many hops you could swim in them like scooge mcduck in a vault full of pennies.  this beer is a woman, she plays with you and ultimately leaves you feeling ethereal.  this lady is "the one" you think, you ponder that you must move to grand rapids and be with her forever.  after all, her brother  breakfast stout is a good addition to your sunday morning foursome.
this is my shift beer at work.  when im broke it is my beer of choice, but mostly for the aesthetic value of the bottle.  i

i dont really understand the 98 percentile.  this beer is good and well-balanced but not really complex or interesting.  i like the floral and citrusy nose but the beer is a murky amber color.  the head is white and lacy. the mouthfele is chalky and chewy.  definitely a good ipa to give to a novice as an introduction but lacking those special, unique qualities
on tap @ the map room

whoa, what a beer.  this hits and it hits hard.  i mean stand up when you pour but sit down when you drink it.  i have always been a "malty man" but with every great ipa  i am becoming hoppier and happier.  not for the meek, this one is for those who have worked their way up.  i can talk about the notes of citrus fruit (early season, bitter navels) or the caramel undertone but make no mistake this beer is a sacrifice to the hop gods.  thanks stone.
nice oatmeal stout.  hints of vanilla, oats, nutmeg, and roastiness.  mmmm roastiness.  not much lacing but a good palate.  i love this   stout series from dark horse.

good scotch ale. nice and malty with an undertone of hoppiness that barely comes through.  notes of caramel, peat, and limestone? intersting beer with a silky, chalky mouthfeel.
on tap @ the maproom
beer_name: Dark Horse Scotty Karate Scotch Ale

review_blob:
pours a rustic amber with a nice big head.  great balnce and notes of citrus and grass.  good but not great.
on tap @ the map room

this beer is amazing, truly unique.  pours a golden color with a big ole lacy head.  aromas and notes of citrus fruit, grass, honeysuckle.  does a nice earthy, yeasty, sour turn in the mouth.  this beer is complex and intriguing, multiple food pairings are possible.
